newsitem.title: GERMANY: EC gas directive talks seen starting soon.
newsitem.headline: EC gas directive talks seen starting soon.

text.p: The European Commission is ready to begin talks on a natural gas directive after the adoption of its electricity directive in June this year, a senior industry figure said on Tuesday.

Bernard Leblanc, senior vice president of Gaz de France told a news conference here that discussions on the gas directive, which will open up gas markets progressively across the European Union, will start shortly.
"Discussions on the electricity directive lasted eight years but I hope it will be faster in the case of gas," he said.
The electricity directive opens up the market gradually so that eventually users of more than nine gigaWatt hours will be able to buy from different suppliers.
Around 20 to 25 percent of the market will be covered by the directive, including most large industrial end users.
Leblanc said that Gaz de France has drawn several lessons from the electricity directive which can be applied to gas.

"First, the electricity directive allows a differentiated approach for the various member states. In effect, it allows members several options while leading to the same level of market opening," he said.
"Second, it recognises that member states have the right to impose public service obligations in the general economic interest," he added.
This allows governments to undertake long term planning in such areas as security of supply and environmental protection.
"And lastly the directive allows for progressive implementation," he added.
But Leblanc was keen to point out that the electricity directive should not be seen as a blueprint for natural gas, because of the fundamental differences between the two.
"There is a basic inequality between various member states: some are blessed with considerable resources and others are not," he said.
Countries had different interests depending on whether or not they produced gas.
"Also, much more gas than electricity is traded across borders," he said.

Physical exchanges of electricity are low, while some dependent gas consumers import 100 percent of their requirements. As a result, electricity has only local implications while gas has geopolitical ramifications.
"Added to that is the fact that the EU's already high dependence on natural gas from outside the region will continue to grow", he said.
That dependence is now 40 percent, rising to 50 percent in 2000 and to 60 percent in 2010.
"One must not be blinded by the temporary British gas bubble", he added.
Gaz de France believes the European Commission must consider several factors to allow the directive to work smoothly.
High among these are allowing companies to conclude long term contracts while finding a solution to the "take or pay" problems on existing contracts.
"All gas companies should find lessons in the recent example provide by British Gas on take or pay. This issue must be resolved before the introduction of any institutional amendment," he said.
Leblanc, attending the third International Energy Agency gas conference here, was upbeat about the prospects for growth in the European gas market.

"The gas resources accessible for European markets at a reasonable price are abundant. They will not actually be available, however, unless the rules of the institutional game do not threaten fundamental balances."
--Sebastian Alison, Berlin Newsroom
